data.name: 6 Day Cappadocia, Gobeklitepe, Mt.Nemrut and Antep Private Tour from Istanbul
data.description: Welcome to the central and south-eastern part of Turkey! This tour will take you to some of the most amazing and historical sites in the area, including Cappadocia, Mt.Nemrut, Gobeklitepe, Sanliurfa and Gaziantep.Cappadocia is known for its stunning landscapes, with its unique rock formations and underground cities. You'll have the chance to explore these underground cities, as well as visit the famous Goreme Open Air Museum, which showcases the region's rich history and culture.Gobeklitepe is another important stop on this tour. This ancient site is home to the world's oldest known temple, dating back over 11,000 years. It is a truly remarkable place and a must-see for anyone interested in ancient civilizations.You'll also visit the cities of Sanliurfa and Gaziantep, both of which are rich in history and culture. In Sanliurfa, you'll have the chance to visit the famous Balikligol(Holy Pond), a sacred pond home to thousands of fish. In Gaziantep, you'll be able to explore the city's rich culinary tradition and visit its many museums and historical sites.Overall, this tour is a fantastic opportunity to explore the history, culture, and natural beauty of Cappadocia and the surrounding region. We hope you have an incredible time and create unforgettable memories!Feel the same atmosphere of first Christian groups in the unique caves of CappadociaConquer the scenery of Cappadocia from up above: Hot Air BalloonsWatch the sunset on Mt. Nemrut, throne of the gods of Commagane KingdomDiscover zero point of history Gobeklitepe Temple and birthplace of prophet AbrahamTaste foods of Gaziantep, gastronomical capital of Turkey

data.name: Bosphorus Cruise Plus Dolmabahce Palace and Two Continents - Combo
data.description: Golden Horn (from the bus), the arm of the Bosphorus and a natural harbour of the historical peninsula separating the old and the new parts of stanbul where the first colonies settled during the Byzantines. The residential area for Byzantine Jews, Italian traders and other non-muslim minorities. Drive along the traces of history at Balat viewing Metal Church of St. Stephen the Bulgarian, Jewish Hospital (Or-Ahayim), Fener Orthodox Patriarchate and 22 kms. long Byzantine City Walls, strongest fortification of the middle age. Spice Bazaar (Egyptian Bazaar), mystical smells of different aromas of various spices. Shops selling fruits, vegetables, fish, flowers etc. Bosphorus Cruise, through the waterway separating the two continents, Europe and Asia, with a possibility to take photographs of marble palaces, ancient wooden villas of Ottoman architecture besides modern residentials and luxurious apartments. Rumeli Fortress (from the boat no interior visit), historical armament built by the Conqueror to control and protect the Bosphorus. A unique example of military architecture. (Visit to a leather showroom if time permits) Lunch at a Turkish Restaurant. Dolmabahe Palace, recent residence for Ottoman Sultans built by two Ottoman architects Karabet and Nikogos Balyan on a 110.000 m area and served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire. Famous with great collection of European antiquity, furniture and 4.5 tons chandelier, the palace has 285 rooms and 46 halls. Bosphorus Bridge, unique chance to step from one continent (Europe) to another (Asia) in 2 minutes. amlca Hill or Yeditepe, panoramic view of stanbul and Bosphorus from one of the highest and most appealing place of the city

data.name: Best Highlights of Istanbul with Private Guide
data.description: Along the way and with the help of our professionally licenced, passionate guides well give you an insight into what makes Istanbul so very special.. The city is captivating, enchanting, vibrant, historical, cultural, romantic and totally unique as it spans two continents. This classical day tour includes the main attractions of Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Grand Bazaar.

data.name: In Trace of Christianity - Half Day Private Tour
data.description: A journey through this part of the world often has the quality of a pilgrimage, a both physical and spiritual search for the origins and realities of ones faith. After Constantine the Greats declaration of Christianity as the religion of the Roman Empire, the capital moved from Rome to Byzantium. With the conquest of Ottoman Empire in 1453, the seat of the Patriarchate remained in Istanbul and the city has since then been the capital for Orthodox Christianity. The church commands a loyalty of about 250 million faithful. You will start the tour by visiting the Patriarchate of Fener by the Golden Horn which is the heart of Orthodox Christianity. Visit the Church of Panagia of Blachernae is the best known and most celebrated shrine of the Holy Virgin. Then well see St. Savior in Chora, originally a Byzantine Monastery with fantastic frescoes and mosaics portraying scenes from the Bible. Next, visit the complex of Christ Pantocrator, one of the largest and best organized of the Byzantine period. See Zoodochos Pege at Balikli, dedicated to the Mother of God at Pege, holding a well-known miracle and the fountain of holy water believed to cure many diseases. Well also visit St.Sergius & Bachus, and Hagia Sophia which for many centuries was the largest church of Christendom, dedicated to Divine Wisdom. Finally we reach Hagia Eirene, the patriarchal church and the Church of St. Mary Pammacaristos which housed the Patriarchate for some time after the conquest.

data.name: Istanbul: City Highlights Tour w/Hagia Sophia & Blue Mosque
data.description: This morning tour delves into Istanbul's rich Byzantine heritage, showcasing architectural marvels and a bustling marketplace.Byzantine Delights:Hippodrome: Step back in time at the ancient Hippodrome, once the center of sporting activities. Marvel at the four iconic monuments:The German Fountain of Wilhelm II Egyptian Obelisk Serpentine Column Walled Obelisk Blue Mosque: Witness the architectural grandeur of the Blue Mosque, Istanbul's most famous landmark, renowned for its dazzling blue Iznik tiles.Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque: Be awestruck by the Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque, an architectural marvel with a fascinating history. Originally a Byzantine basilica built by Constantine the Great, it was reconstructed by Justinian in the 6th century.Shopping Paradise:Grand Bazaar: Immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere of the Grand Bazaar, a labyrinthine marketplace overflowing with over 4,000 shops. The tour concludes at the Grand Bazaar, where you can explore further at your own pace or use public transportation to return to your hotel.This enriching walking tour provides a captivating exploration of Istanbul's Byzantine legacy and vibrant marketplace, leaving you with a lasting impression.

data.name: Hagia Sophia: Skip The Line Ticket + Audio Guide
data.shortDescription: Set off on a 1500-year Byzantine history tour
data.description:
Hagia Sophia is a must-see landmark in Istanbul. Built in 537 as a church by Emperor Justinian, it was the world's largest church for centuries. After the Ottomans took over in 1453, Sultan Mehmed II turned it into a mosque. In 1935, it became a museum, and in 2020, a mosque again.

Hagia Sophia blends Christian and Islamic features. Inside, you'll find mosaics of Jesus and Mary alongside Islamic elements like the mihrab and minarets. 

The architecture features a large dome, tall columns, and golden mosaics. Key features include the Imperial Door and marble columns  a striking example of Byzantine and Ottoman design. Hagia Sophia stands as a symbol of faith, culture, and history.

data.name: Whirling Dervishes Live Show
data.shortDescription: Witness the transcendental pray of dervishes in this historic house in Istanbul
data.description:
This special ceremony in a unique environment reveals the spiritual character of Istanbul and Turkish people outside of the **Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque.** 

A poetic experience, Sufi whirling brings dervishes closer to God as they spin in repetitive circles. The original name _Sema_ has two meanings  the skies and hearing. The dervishes are raising their hands while whirling to feel the universe, its creation and motion. This is the way to reach maturity as a human being in an ecstatic moment full of love.

The historic venue sets the stage as the whirling dervishes come forward to lift the curtain between the body and soul, their dress lifting hypnotically serving as a meaningful metaphor.

data.name: Blue Mosque Guided Tour + Hagia Sophia Skip The Line Ticket
data.shortDescription: Hear captivating stories and see famous blue tiles up close
data.description:
Take a personal tour of Istanbul's history, starting with the Blue Mosque, plus skip-the-line admission to Hagia Sophia.

Your adventure begins in the busy heart of the Old City, where an expert guide meets you near the Blue Mosque.

First, visit the Blue Mosque, known for its blue tiles. Built by Sultan Ahmet, its architecture is a highlight, with the guide sharing stories of its history.

Next, explore Hagia Sophia. Learn about its znik tiles, the Virgin Mary mosaic, and the tradition of interring sultans in its courtyard.

data.name: Basilica Cistern: Fast Track Ticket + Audio Guide
data.shortDescription: Explore an underground marvel and view intricate Medusa heads
data.description:
Get ready for an adventure with an all-day ticket to the stunning **Basilica Cistern** in Istanbul! Skip the lines with this online ticket and save up to two hours. Plus, get a free audio guide to help you explore.

Go beneath Istanbul's busy streets and witness the beauty of the Basilica Cistern. See the remarkable architecture in this dimly lit underground cavern and learn about the Byzantine Empire as you explore this historic site.

Walk through the grandeur of the cistern, and take in the intricate Medusa heads, relics of Greek mythology. The audio guide shares the cistern's fascinating history, making your visit engaging and informative.

Feel free to take as many photos as you like. This ticket isn't time bounded and  allows you all the time you need to take in one of Istanbul's top attractions.

data.name: Theodosius Cistern: Skip The Line Ticket
data.description:
Visit the cistern to see the Byzantine Empire's engineering skills and learn about Constantinople's history.

Observe the construction techniques and architectural design that have lasted for centuries. See the 32 marble columns with intricate capitals, now illuminated by modern lighting that highlights their details.

data.name: Topkap Palace Museum: Guided Tour with Harem Section
data.description:
Live a sultan's life for a day here at the most visited museum in Turkey! Join your guide and get an in-depth tour of the Topkap Palace, home to Ottoman rulers for over half a century. Learn about the conquest of Constantinople, see the arms room, treasury, and more! A must-do tour in Istanbul.

Learn what happened in each building and courtyard, from the treasury to the apartments, bathhouses, and armory. The mighty Topkap Palace is a grandiose statement of Turkish progress, from its roots as a feudal society to a thriving influential empire spanning 600 years.

Gaze up at the Imperial Gate and witness the beauty of the First Courtyard. Cross through the giant Gate of Salutation into the Second Courtyard, where Sultan Selim III held ceremonial assemblies and conducted important state affairs.

data.name: Hagia Sophia Mosque: Skip the Line Guided Tour
data.description:
Meet your guide near the Hagia Sophia and start your tour with a walk to the monument. Learn about the history, the old city, and the blend of Christian and Islamic heritage. Discover the architecture of the Ottoman and Byzantine empires.

Inside the Hagia Sophia, your guide will show you how to use the Augmented Reality (AR) app and audio guide so you can explore all the highlights together. After the tour, you can stay inside as long as you want.

Walk through the nave and visit the upper galleries for great views. See the mosaics of biblical scenes and calligraphic panels up close and experience the calm atmosphere of this historic site.

data.name: Hagia Sophia: Guided Tour + Bosphorus Cruise
data.description:
Begin with a visit to Hagia Sophia. This site has transformed from a Christian church to a mosque and now serves as a museum. Stand beneath its dome, view the mosaics, and learn about its long history.

After exploring Hagia Sophia, take a Bosphorus cruise. Sail along Istanbul's shoreline, passing historic palaces, mosques, and fortresses. From the boat, see both the European and Asian sides of the city and enjoy a new perspective of Istanbul's skyline. As you continue the cruise, look at the bridges that connect the continents.

Next, you will take a peaceful Bosphorus cruise. You will see Istanbul's skyline, historical forts, palaces, and the Bosphorus Bridge.

Combining a cultural tour with a relaxing cruise, this trip offers a complete view of Istanbul's heritage and beauty.

data.name: Istanbul: Sand-Brewed Turkish Coffee Workshop in Sultanahmet
data.description:
Learn how to make Turkish coffee using the traditional sand method in Istanbul.

This workshop blends history, flavor, and culture as you learn a method from the 16th century Ottoman Empire, using a copper pot (cezve) placed on heated sand for slow brewing.

During the session, enjoy the rich, aromatic cup and listen to the cultural stories behind this age-old tradition.

data.name: Istanbul Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum with Audioguide
data.description: The Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum, is a cultural treasure trove, offering you an enthralling peek into the rich legacy of Islamic art. Nestled within the historic Ibrahim Pasha Palace, this museum boasts an extensive collection of exquisite artifacts from diverse regions and spanning centuries.One of the standout features of this museum is its vast assortment of carpets and rugs. These intricate textiles, adorned with vivid hues and complex patterns, provide a visual banquet for your eyes. From ancient Seljuk designs to ornate Ottoman masterpieces, the carpets on display exemplify the exceptional craftsmanship of Islamic weavers.In addition to carpets, you'll find a varied range of artifacts reflecting the artistic accomplishments of Islamic civilizations. You can explore sections dedicated to calligraphy, ceramics, glasswork, and metalwork. Each exhibit provides a distinct insight into the creativity and skill of Islamic artisans throughout history.For those seeking a deeper connection to Islamic heritage, the museum also houses a collection of religious relics, including fragments of the Prophet Muhammad's beard and a footprint. These artifacts hold significant religious and historical value.Whether you're a history buff, an art aficionado, or simply looking for a cultural experience, the Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum has something to offer everyone.

data.name: Unmissable Istanbul classics private guided tour
data.description: Meet your tour guide in your hotel or at the port and start the tour with the highlights of Istanbul.Visit Hagia Sophia where the ancient cultures of East and West speak to you with a clear voice. This building is a great blend of Christian and Islamic influences with a beautiful interior of impressive mosaics and a very significant history. Learn about its history since it was built in the 6th century by Emperor Justinian. Head to the Hippodrome, where the chariot races were held during the Roman Empire. Go to the German Fountain which is a must-see monument in Istambul.Blue Mosque, built in the early 1600s for Sultan Ahmet I. Admire this truly magnificent masterpiece of architecture with amazingly delicate proportions for a building of such a massive scale. The blue shade of the 27.000 pieces of Iznik quartz tiles gives the mosque its name and 6 towering minarets give it its uniquely recognizable structure. Then, explore the Grand Bazaar which is one of the biggest markets in the world with over 4000 shops. Visit Topkapi Palace, an imperial residence of Ottoman sultans.

data.name: 500 year old historical Turkish bath experience
data.description: Enjoy an authentic Turkish bath experience and feel refreshed! Located in the heart of the Historical Peninsula, at walking distance from Grand Bazaar and serving since 1584, the Historical emberlita Hammam is the best place for an authentic Turkish bath experience!The Turkish Bath is a traditional type of public bathing which is essentially based on the ancient Roman bathing culture and the principles of the steam bath. Together with the traditional Turkish bath massage (Turkish scrub), it became an integral part of the Turkish culture as well as an important part of social life. After sweating, the person in charge of scrubbing and foaming will scrub all the dead skin from your body. After foaming, you can relax as long as you want in the Hammam.

Afterwards, enjoy a splendid panoramic view of Istanbul city from Camlica Hill, widely referred to as the Lovers' Hill.

Beylerbeyi Palace closed on Monday / Replaced with Chora Museum

Haghia Sophia was built as a church in the 6th century by Emperor Justinian then in 1453 renovated into a mosque by Ottoman Emperor Fatih Sultan Mehmet. It was converted into a museum in 1935 and welcoming both local and foreign visitors. (Closed on Monday)

Blue Mosque, as known as the Sultanahmet Mosque, this breath-taking building is one of the most majestic Ottoman Mosques in all of Turkey. Also it was built with unique 6 minarets. (Closed on Friday)

After tour we will drop you off to your hotel.

data.name: 2-Day Troy and Gallipoli Tour from Istanbul
data.description:
Day 1: Istanbul Gallipoli anakkale (L)Early in the morning, meet your guide in central Istanbul and hop aboard your comfy coach for a voyage to Gallipolis historic battlefields. Along the way stop briefly for a quick bite to eat (own expense).

After about a four hour journey, arrive in Gallipoli and learn about the long and dreadful WWI campaign fought here between the Ottoman Turks and Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (ANZAC). ANZAC, who was a member of the Allies, followed orders to sack Constantinople, but were met by a surprisingly determined Ottoman Turk army who battled them to a standstill. Hear about the thousands who fell in Gallipoli during nearly eight months of fighting as you walk with your guide through this historic site.

Begin your walking tour exploring the most interesting battlefields and observing quaint memorials which are visited by many foreigners every year. See the most poignant Australian memorial site - Lone Pine. Then stroll to the trenches of the Nek while learning about the soldiers who attacked from the nearby forest.

Next, head to Chunuk Bair New Zealand Memorial and discover a rare battleground where Allied troops were triumphant, but only for a short period. Continue to ANZAC Cove, where most battles were fought, and pay your heartfelt respects to the troops who died here. Then, stroll through Ari Burnu Cemetery and see where 200 servicemen lay forever. Observe more memorials at Beach Cemetery, Brighton Beach, and the somber trenches at Johnsons Jolly.

Stop for lunch about midway through your tour and enjoy plenty of opportunities for leisure time to continue sightseeing on your own. Then, meet your guide at a predetermined time and drive to your accommodation in central anakkale where you will have more free time.

Lodging: 3-star Byk Truva Hotel or Grand Anzac Hotel in central anakkale

Day 2: anakkale Troy Istanbul (B, L)After breakfast depart from your hotel with your guide and head to Nusrat minelayer and Cimenlik Castle. Start the day with a walking tour and learn how Troy evolved from a series of small villages and became a Bronze Age dwelling only to fall as a Byzantine town. With your guide, hear about the ancient history of Troy and the Greek mythology of the Trojan War, a 10-year war started by the Trojan prince (Paris) who took off with Zeus daughter (Helen). Admire these historical ruins and then see the timber built Trojan Horse, the towns icon. Afterward, spend some free time snapping photos and walking around.

Next, head to lunch at a restaurant nearby, before continuing through one of the most famous archaeological sites in the world, the 4,000 year old ancient city of Troy. Learn how Troy is thought to be the first place where people connected from the Mediterranean region and Anatolia (ancient Asia). Finally, hop back on your coach and return to your Istanbul lodging where your tour ends in the late evening.

data.name: Full-Day Ephesus Ancient City Tour
data.description: Journey to the ancient city of Ephesus on a private guided tour from Istanbul. Roundtrip airfare makes it easy for you to get to Ephesus and maximize your time exploring significant ancient sites including the Temple of Artemis, one of the seven wonders of the world, along with the Isa Bey Mosque, and Meryemana, the final home of the Virgin Mary. Along the way, you'll learn about the Greek, Roman, and Byzantine civilizations that once occupied this region.

data.name: Private Istanbul By Night Tour
data.description: Istanbul takes on a different persona by night when its sights glow with lights and locals pack the streets and restaurants. Drink in the citys night-time energy, see its illuminated landmarks from the outside and beat the blazing sun at the same time on this private tour. Admire Sultanahmets floodlit Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque, absorb the buzz of Istiklal Street and Taksim, stop for drinks (own expense) and view much more, all with your guide providing insight and navigation.

data.name: Istanbul Ottoman Tour Including Topkapi Palace and Blue Mosque
data.description:
Meet your guide at your central hotel in Istanbul and begin your tour of the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace. Hop aboard your convenient ride and head to the Blue Mosque (also referred to as Sultan Ahmet Mosque) one of the premier attractions in Turkey and an important Islamic monument. Built during Ottoman rule under the direction of Sultan Ahmet, admire the six minarets that tower over the dome structure. Then, observe the main chambers 20,000 Iznik tiles that are illuminated by 260 windows.

Next, head to Topkapi Palace, the illustrious pinnacle of the Ottoman Empire. Visit one of the worlds oldest and largest palaces full of elegant chambers and heirloom treasures. Stroll with your guide and delve into the interesting history of this palace that sits along the coastline of the Golden Horn.

Continue from Topkapi Palace to the former heart and soul of Constantinople's sporting and political center, the Hippodrome. Learn about this lively area which for 500 years was home to Ottoman sports and even riots! Now a city park called At Meydan (Horse Grounds), hear how it drew its name from former chariot races. Then, walk with your guide to the ancient granite Obelisk and discover how it was transported from Egypt to Constantinople by Emperor Theodosius in the late 4th century.

Finish your tour with a ride back to your Istanbul hotel.

Please note: On Fridays the Blue Mosque will be closed until 2:30pm for prayer, entry will not be permitted and on Tuesdays Topkapi Palace is closed.

data.description:
istanbul visitors hoping to snap some fantastic vacation photos shouldn't settle for smartphone selfies when you can book a photographer to take great photos for you. data.name: Half Day Private Guided Ottoman Royal Tour in Topkapi Palace
data.description: Topkapi Palace was the residence of the Ottoman Sultans for more than 400 years and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This tour is a private tour that allows for a more personalized and intimate experience. A private guide can tailor the tour to your interests and provide insights and information that you may not get in a larger group tour. The tour focuses on Ottoman history, culture, and architecture, which is unique to the Topkapi Palace. You will learn about the Ottoman Empire's history and see the art and architecture that reflects the empire's grandeur and magnificence. It offers exclusive access to the palace's private chambers, which are not accessible to the general public. You will be able to see the lavish lifestyle of the Ottoman Sultans and their families in their private quarters. Topkapi Palace houses a vast collection of artifacts and objects that are unique to the Ottoman Empire.

data.name: Basilica Cistern Small Group, Live Guide. w/Skip-the-Line Ticket
data.description:
Visit the Basilica Cistern, built in the 4th century and enlarged in 532 AD, used as water storage during Byzantine times. Listen to your guide as they explain the mystery of Medusa heads from Greek mythology.

Explore this cathedral-sized cistern, built during the reign of Emperor Justinian I in 532 A.D. to supply water to the Great Palace. It stores up to 80,000 cubic meters of water, delivered via 20 kilometers of aqueducts from a reservoir near the Black Sea.

Descend the fifty-two stone steps into the entrance of the cistern. The cistern is surrounded by a firebrick wall with a thickness of 4 meters, coated with a waterproofing mortar. Hear how the Basilica Cistern's water comes from the Erikap Water Distribution Center in the Belgrade Forest and travels through the 971-meter-long Valens Aqueduct and the 115-meter-long Malova Aqueduct, built by the Emperor Justinian.

data.name: Istanbul: Bosphorus and Golden Horn Cruise with Audio Guide
data.description:
Sail through the Bosphorus Strait and along the Golden Horn as you see Istanbul's most famous sights on this sightseeing tour.

Hop on a sightseeing cruise to tour the Golden Horn and the Bosphorus. Get a fresh look at Istanbul on this boat tour with an audio guide to tell you all the top tales as you glide by Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Maiden's Tower, and Galata Tower. Sail as far south to see the iconic Bosphorus Bridge.

Meet your host on the other side of Hagia Sophia and walk down to the pier behind the grand mosque. Jump on board to discover the Golden Horn, considered to be the worlds largest natural harbor. Sail through the magnificent Bosphorus strait forming the continental boundary between Asia and Europe.

Admire the Bosphorus coastline on the European side from the cruise, and see a string of villages, each with its own individual character and attractions. Glide past Dolmabahe Palace, Ciragan Palace, Ortaky Mosque, and the Bosphorus Bridge, among others.

data.name: Cappadocia with Ozkonak Underground City from Istanbul
data.description:
In the morning, meet your chauffeur at your Istanbul hotel for a transfer to Istanbul Airport and begin your day adventure to Cappadocia. After short flight, land at Kayseri International Airport and meet your air-conditioned minivan for a 1.5-hour ride to beautiful Rose Valley.

Arrive and begin a relaxing walking tour with your local guide. Learn about the rose-colored rocks whose tone changes during the day is the reason for Rose Valleys etymology. Then, marvel at the valleys weathered volcanic monoliths, craggy pinnacles, fairy chimneys and dense orchards and vineyards. Continue to Rose Valleys cave churches and hear how their were used by monks before the end of the first millennium.

Onward to a historical deserted rock village filled with ancient houses and churches, known as Old avuin. Here, capture stunning shots of creepy houses and admire the imposing Basilica of St John the Baptist which rests on a clifftop overlooking avuin.

Take a break for lunch at a traditional restaurant (see the sample menu below in the Itinerary) and then head to the old town of Ortahisar to gaze up at the commanding presence of Ortahisar Castle, a Byzantine-era fortification. Stand in awe as you view this 295-foot monolith chiseled into the image of a giant honeycomb. Climb up its narrow passage and pass carved rooms and etched out chambers. At the top, glimpse over the city for remarkable views.

Next, voyage to Kaymakli Underground City and delve into the winding network of subsurface tunnels, living quarters, stables, kitchens and cellars. Hear how this well preserved city was once home to Christians who sought refuge from persecution.

Finally, spend time looking at astounding cave homes at Pigeon Valley. Learn about locals who bred pigeons in their homes to collect poop for fertilizer! As the day comes to a close, journey back to Kayseri Airport to catch your flight to Istanbul. Then, enjoy a transfer back to your hotel where your tour ends.

Please note: Ortahisar Castle may be undertaking renovation, if it is entrance will not be permitted.

data.name: Istanbul Private Ottoman Empire Tour Including Topkapi Palace
data.description:
Meet your local guide at your Istanbul hotel (European side only) or at a central meeting point and hop into your air-conditioned minivan to begin your private tour of the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace. Listen as your guide runs through the 4-hour tour itinerary, but note the order to visit each landmark is subject to change.

At last, set off towards the life blood of Istanbul - the Sultanahmet neighborhood. Stroll through this UNESCO World Heritage Site and discover the Hippodrome. Here, learn about day to day Ottoman-life in this extensive arena. Go back in time hundreds of years to feel the heartbeat of this ancient citys political gatherings, sports, and even riots! Next, listen as your guide explains how this area has become fun for both locals and visitors. Perhaps, bust a move for a photo in front of the ancient Obelisk of Theodosius which was brought over from Egypt in 390 AD by the Emperor.

Next, wander over to the Blue Mosque and stare up towards the six towering minarets. Then, quietly enter this house of worship and admire the thousands of detailed Iznik tiles that illuminate the domes walls in a brilliant blue. See this perfect example of Ottoman architecture and learn why Sultan Ahmet, who ordered its construction, was adamant about building a place of worship to contend with the stunning beauty of neighboring Hagia Sophia.

After snapping photos and staring into the magnificent dome above, cruise to the final attraction Topkapi Palace. Explore this illustrious palace home to peculiar 15th-century sultans. Then, learn about day to day life of the palaces harems, princes, and eunuch servants. Now that Topkapi Palace has settled down into a fine museum, wander through its exhibits to see royal armor and weapons, ancient artifacts and read tales about the famous people who once resided in Istanbuls most opulent palace.

After exiting Topkapi Palace, walk along a tree-laden path with your guide to your minivan. Climb aboard and cruise back to your start point in central Istanbul or to your hotel on the European side.

Please note: on Fridays the Blue Mosque cannot be visited due to 2.30pm prayer, instead you will visit Rustem Pasha Mosque.

data.name: Istanbul 3-Hour Byzantine Empire Tour with Church of St Mary
data.description:
Meet your guide at your hotel for pickup or in the Istanbul neighborhood of Yenikapi for your Constantinople history tour. Buckle up in your luxurious coach for a cruise around the Golden Horn. Learn how this natural bay links with the Bosphorus Strait and created a once prominent shipping harbor for Byzantine trade.

Next, admire the Ecumencial Orthodox Patriarchate in the Greek district of Fener. Gain insight about the liturgical leader of the Greek Orthodox Church who is based here. Closeby, see Church of St George (the sites primary church) and observe the elegantly decorated Byzantine patriarchal seat.

Drive on to the district of Ayvansaray, formerly called Blachernae during Byzantine times, and observe the historical Eastern Orthodox church Church of St Mary of Blachernae. While this churchs architecture is not a typical beauty, its significance in the Eastern Orthodox Community is important since the shrine of the Holy Virgin is worshipped within. With your guide enter the church and gaze over the holy water spring.

Onwards to another important Byzantine monastery in the Western district. Stop and visit the beautiful Chora Church and relish its fresco painted walls. Hear from your guide how the details were far beyond the rest of Byzantine artwork. Then, marvel at the vibrant mosaics within that create an entrancing ambiance.

Loop back to Ayvansaray and uncover the history within the venerable Blachernae Palace. Observe the ruins of this once grand palace and soak in the greatness that once thrived here. Let your imagination soak up frightful feeling as you observe the Byzantine prison exterior known as the Anemas Dungeons. Then, see the outside of the Tekfur Palace (or spend time at Palace of Constantine Porphyrogenitus) the Blachernae Palaces last remaining building.

Finally, promenade beside the Walls of Constantinople, and enjoy the ruins of this old citys gates and towers. After a day becoming a Byzantine history buff, hop back on your coach and head to the center of the Sultanahmet neighborhood where your tour ends.
